sense.def: a small piece of equipment that does a particular job, especially a new type
dictionaryExamples: a kitchen gadget
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that robots and hi-tech gadgets will definitely invade our private and profes[s]ional life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to get something useful or positive, especially over a period of time
dictionaryExamples: After you've gained some experience teaching abroad you can come home and get a job.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must explain to them that you need to gain some experience. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to increase in something such as size, weight, or amount
dictionaryExamples: He's gained a lot of weight in the last few months.

sense.def: when you get something useful or positive
dictionaryExamples: financial/personal gain

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim of this report is to describe the gain or loss of respect of some jobs in Spain, explaining why this has occurred and talking about the future changes in job status. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: an increase in something such as size, weight, or amount
dictionaryExamples: Side effects of the medication may include tiredness, headaches or weight gain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consumption of pre-cooked meals, fast food, [and] canned food not only results in weight gain but also cause[s] health problems. International English Language Testing System; C1; Turkish

sense.def: a room or building which is used for showing works of art
dictionaryExamples: the National Portrait Gallery
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then [there] are a lot of museums and art galleries which you could visit. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

dictionaryExamples: He gambled away all of her savings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact on the first night they almost gambled it all away, but John got lucky at the last minute and won 25 thousand dollars. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity of betting money, for example in a game or on a horse race

sense.def: an entertaining activity or sport that people play

sense.def: a particular competition, match or occasion when people play a game
dictionaryExamples: We played a game of volleyball.

He didn't want to join their gang.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was two days ago. I wanted to [join] Joe's gang, but [first] I had to prove my courage. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a group of criminals who work together

sense.def: a difference between two things

sense.def: something that is absent and stops something from being complete

sense.def: a small building, often next to a house, that you can put a car in

sense.def: a business that repairs cars, and sometimes also sells fuel
dictionaryExamples: The car's still at the garage getting fixed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took it to the garage and they are fixing [it] now but it will take time to repair it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: food waste and other things that you throw away because you do not want them

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The streets are dirty and smell bad and here [there isn't] a big place to throw the garbage away. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a piece of land belonging to a house, where flowers and other plants are grown

sense.def: public places where flowers, trees, and other plants are grown for people to enjoy

sense.def: someone who works in a garden, growing plants and making it look attractive

sense.def: the job or activity of growing a garden and keeping it attractive

sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  After four years [of] studying and doing the A level exam, I still don't have any qualification in gardening, but I really like flowers and plants. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: a vegetable like a small onion with a very strong taste and smell
dictionaryExamples: a clove of garlic

sense.def: a piece of clothing
dictionaryExamples: They were luxurious garments, made of silk and velvet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their garments consisted of four layers of robes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a liquid fuel used in cars and trucks
dictionaryExamples: the gas tank
gas mileage
We need to stop and get gas.

sense.def: a substance in a form like air that is used as a fuel for heating and cooking
dictionaryExamples: a gas stove
Do you prefer cooking with electricity or gas?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can also see how life [is] in our African villages, where there [is] no electricity or gas and where water comes only from the river. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a substance in a form like air that is neither solid nor liquid
dictionaryExamples: Oxygen, hydrogen and nitrogen are all gases.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All people know that CO2 is a very dangerous gas for all kind[s] of animals. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: gas, a liquid fuel for cars and trucks
dictionaryExamples: regular/unleaded gasoline
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Actually we know that gasoline is very expensive. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a noise by suddenly breathing in because you are shocked or surprised

dictionaryExamples: a gasp of surprise
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His gasp startled the other sleeping tourists & they all crawled and stumbled onto their feet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a place where you buy gas for a car
dictionaryExamples: Where's the nearest gas station?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's on your left, near the gas station. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the part of a fence or outside wall that opens and closes like a door
dictionaryExamples: Please close the gate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's meet at the school gate. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a part of an airport where passengers get on or off an aircraft

sense.def: to join other people somewhere to make a group, or to bring people together into a group
dictionaryExamples: A crowd had gathered to hear her speak.

She gathered the children together and began to tell them a story.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People had gathered in front of a particular painting. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to collect several things, often from different places or people
dictionaryExamples: We gathered our things together and left quickly.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The  payment would be OK, I gather, but we would rely on tips to earn enough money. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to increase in speed/momentum/support, etc.

sense.def: a party or a meeting when many people get together as a group
dictionaryExamples: a family gathering
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Parks, for example, can't be used for [a] barbeque or family gathering in the winter time. International English Language Testing System; C1; Indonesian

sense.def: homosexual
dictionaryExamples: gay rights
Have you told your parents you're gay yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are not a religious person, if you have got divorced and you want to get married again, or if you are gay, you must get married [in a] civil [ceremony]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a set of parts in a motor vehicle or bicycle that control how fast the wheels turn

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has 24 active gears and multilink [K]evl[a]r brakes. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a particular position of the gears in a motor vehicle or bicycle that controls how fast the wheels turn

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wrenched the car into first gear and stormed off to the office. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: the clothes and equipment used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: fishing/camping gear
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll see you in a week and don't forget your cycling gear. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the state of being male or female

sense.def: the division of nouns, pronouns and adjectives into masculine, feminine and neuter types
dictionaryExamples: In English, nouns don't have gender, but in French and Spanish, they do.

sense.def: a part of a cell that is passed on from a parent to a child and that controls particular characteristics
dictionaryExamples: Scientists have discovered the gene responsible for causing this disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it would be reasonable to include capsules with human genes and the genetic material of endangered species. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: not detailed, but including the most basic or necessary information

sense.def: usually, or in most situations

sense.def: usually, or in most situations

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I generally prefer reading newspapers, but I don't dislike books. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of them
dictionaryExamples: My health is generally very good.

sense.def: a product when it is at a particular stage of development

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can sum up the most important things that changed my li[f]e are the telephone, the computer, the portable phone and of course [the] new generation of television. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the production of energy in a particular form

sense.def: the quality of being generous

sense.def: willing to give other people money, help, kindness, etc.

a generous portion

sense.def: in a generous way

genetic research

sense.def: the scientific study of the parts of cells that control particular characteristics (genes)
dictionaryExamples: Next year, I'll be studying genetics.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We use technology in order to save human live[s] and to explore strange new worlds, such as genetics. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: someone who is extremely intelligent or extremely good at doing something
dictionaryExamples: Einstein was a genius.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And what about Mozart - poor little genius! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the quality of being extremely intelligent or extremely good at doing something
dictionaryExamples: Einstein's genius
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nothing is more common than unrewarded genius and mis[used] talents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: kind, calm and careful not to upset or hurt anyone
dictionaryExamples: My mother was such a gentle, loving person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mani  is very kind and gentle. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not violent, severe or strong

a gentle breeze
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather is sunny, the gentle breeze is pure and fresh. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

dictionaryExamples: It was a fairly gentle climb to the summit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: THE TOUR Trained guides lead people across gentle slopes towards thick woods displaying a wide variety of birds and animal life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: calmly, kindly or softly
dictionaryExamples: He held the baby gently in his arms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I am older and I speak to my mother very gently. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

dictionaryExamples: genuine leather
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bicycle is [a] genuine Shimano bicycle. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If a person is genuine or someone's feelings are genuine, they are sincere and honest.
dictionaryExamples: They showed genuine sympathy for our situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, it is well known in environmental management that strategies that work via [the] people's purse are often the only way to motivate people who have little genuine interest in environmental problems (or just too many other concerns). International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: in a genuine or sincere way
dictionaryExamples: I'm genuinely sorry for the extra work this has caused.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are all genuinely interested in English literature. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the study of the physical surface of the Earth and all regions of the world
dictionaryExamples: a degree in geography and economics
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left my geography book at your house yesterday. Key English Test; A2; Assamese

sense.def: the study of rocks and soil and the physical structure of the Earth
dictionaryExamples: a book about geology
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have graduated from school and I am now studying geology at the University of Greece. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a very small living thing that causes disease
dictionaryExamples: Wash your hands before cooking so that you don't spread germs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am more careful with cleaning up and taking care of my baby. It was amazing the way they spoke about germs and dust. International English Language Testing System; C1; Kurdish

sense.def: the beginning of something
dictionaryExamples: the germ of a brilliant idea
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Going back to the scene at More's home, we now understand why this is the germ of the subsequent development of the play. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: A gerund is a noun made from the form of a verb that ends with -ing, for example "fishing" in "John loves fishing."
dictionaryExamples: We learned about gerunds today.

sense.def: a movement you make with your hand, arm, or head to express what you are thinking or feeling
dictionaryExamples: He made a rude gesture to the crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Review - The Body Speaks [...] In the second part, you are taught how to read the gestures, voice, [and] hesitations, and analy[z]e them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: something you do to show people how you feel about a person or situation

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir, I am the secretary of the Student Committee in Bringtown College and I am writing to thank you for your kind gesture [in] inviting me to the opening of the new Arts Cent[e]r. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

dictionaryExamples: He gestured toward the window.

sense.def: to obtain or buy something
dictionaryExamples: I'll get some bread on the way home.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could get the afternoon ticket. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to receive or be given something
dictionaryExamples: I got some very nice presents for my birthday.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got your note. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Nepali

sense.def: to reach or arrive at a particular place
dictionaryExamples: We got home later than usual.
I didn't get to work till nine o'clock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had a good time at your house last night but when I got home I realized I had forg[o]tten my bag! Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to travel somewhere in a bus, train, taxi or other vehicle
dictionaryExamples: Should we get a taxi to the station?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can get the train. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to go somewhere and bring back someone or something

Could you get me my keys from upstairs?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided [to] go on with my plan and get my father's car. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to begin a legal relationship with someone as their husband or wife
dictionaryExamples: They got married in April.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was going to get married, and I was invited to the wedding. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to become ill or develop an illness
dictionaryExamples: I'm getting another cold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was angry, and I got a cold! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to start to be cold/ill/late, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Your coffee's getting cold.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's getting late so I should finish now. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

dictionaryExamples: My cold seems to be getting worse.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought, it couldn't get worse. Preliminary English Test; B1; German
