dictionaryExamples: He got killed in the war.
She got told off in class for not paying attention.
Be careful you don't get bitten in the woods.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two weeks ago many people at school got injured because of an explosion, so a TV company came to film what the school is like now ... Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to produce an answer or result that is not correct, or to say or write something that is not correct
dictionaryExamples: I got most of the answers wrong.
The newspapers got the story completely wrong.

sense.def: to do a task, or to arrange for someone to do a task for you
dictionaryExamples: Could you get the kids dressed?
I need to get my hair cut.
You have to get that form sent off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I have to go to the doctor and then I have to get my teeth checked by the dentist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to contact someone
dictionaryExamples: Please get in touch if you ever come back to Madrid.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Get in touch soon. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to move to a different place or into a different position
dictionaryExamples: I saw her getting into his car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They [said] that I got into a car by myself (they thought that I had believed the story). First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to deal with or answer a ringing telephone, a knock on the door, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Could you get the phone, Al?
Someone's at the door - could you get it?

sense.def: to spend time with someone or something so that you gradually learn more about them
dictionaryExamples: The first couple of meetings are for the doctor and patient to get to know each other.
I'll need a few weeks to get to know the system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you can come here and get to know him. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to throw something away or give something to someone because you no longer want it
dictionaryExamples: We must get rid of some of those old books.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you think I'd better get rid of the sofa and place the bookshelf [there]? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to end something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: I can't seem to get rid of this headache.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] first step is to get rid of smoking. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to make something happen, or make someone or something do something
dictionaryExamples: I can't get my computer to work!
I'll get Ben to fix your bike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We must get the councillors to change their minds. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to develop an opinion about a situation because of something that you notice
dictionaryExamples: I got the feeling that she was really angry about the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I disagree with some points you mentioned and would like to share the impression I got from that popular holiday report during my two-week trip. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to annoy someone, especially by doing something again and again
dictionaryExamples: If we spend too much time together, we end up getting on each other's nerves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes, receiving a phone call can disturb very important events in [a person's] life, but [it] also get[s] on people's nerves when you use it in a public place like a train. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to have the chance to do something
dictionaryExamples: I never got to meet her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I did get to meet a musician, a singer named Anouk. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to understand or hear something
dictionaryExamples: That joke that he told  - did you get it?

sense.def: to make an effort to control your emotions and behave more calmly
dictionaryExamples: Stop panicking and get a grip on yourself!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The best thing to do was to talk to people who were not doing the test rather than building up my anxiety. However, I did not do this and it almost resulted in a disaster, but I got a grip on myself and just barely passed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: to make someone leave
dictionaryExamples: We finally got rid of my little sister by telling her scary stories.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Improving your English on your own (or a self-guide [on] how to get rid of your English teacher!). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to make sure that you completely understand a situation
dictionaryExamples: Let me get this straight - am I paying for this?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Next time you should try to get your facts straight. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to become better organized so that you can make progress
dictionaryExamples: I wish she'd get her act together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was determined to get his act together and try to find a solution to his problem. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to become difficult to control
dictionaryExamples: It was the end of week and the children were getting a little out of hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A few solutions can prevent this problem from getting out of hand. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to learn how to do something, especially if it is not obvious or simple
dictionaryExamples: I've  never used one of these before. - Don't worry, you'll soon get the hang of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was quite hard to get the hang of it, as I didn't have any knowledge of English. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to hurry
dictionaryExamples: We're leaving in five minutes, so get moving!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Oh, look at the time, we must get moving!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to hurry
dictionaryExamples: Come on, get a move on!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "All the lights will be switched off in 28 minut[e]s, so I have to get a move on," I said to myself, as I started to write on a new piece of paper. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: If something gets you nowhere, it does not help you to succeed.
dictionaryExamples: Bad manners will get you nowhere.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As this is a loophole in [the] law system, it's creating a conflict between house-owners and squatters and getting them nowhere. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: used to say that someone understands a situation
dictionaryExamples: Oh right, I get the picture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you use a photograph though, you can be sure that everyone will get the picture (pun intended) and pro[b]ably remember the person you're talking about next time they see him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to begin
dictionaryExamples: The film festival gets underway on July 11th.

sense.def: to tell someone about something that you have been worried or angry about for a long time
dictionaryExamples: Tell me what's wrong - you'll feel better if you get it off your chest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Chris is always caring and lends you his ear if there's something you need to get off your chest. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrasalVerb: get across sth or get sth across

sense.def: to manage to make someone understand or believe something
dictionaryExamples:
We tried to get our point across, but he just wouldn't
                             listen.
This is the message that we want to get across to the public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am going to get across several ideas to improve the look of our town. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to have a good relationship
dictionaryExamples: She and her new roommate are getting along.
He doesn't get along with his daughter.
I get along well with most of her friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a journalist at the local newspaper and we get along very well. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to travel or move from place to place
dictionaryExamples: The busses and subway make it easy to get around New York City.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The island isn't too big so I think we could get around on foot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to do something that you have intended to do for a long time
dictionaryExamples: I still haven't got around to fixing that faucet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Kim, I am terribly sorry not to drop you a line since the last time we wrote to one another. But I finally got around [to] writing and you'll see that it's defin[i]t[e]ly worth waiting as I have some great and unbeli[e]vable news to tell you. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to be able to reach or get something
dictionaryExamples: I've put the cake on a high shelf where the kids can't get at it.

sense.def: If you ask someone what they are getting at, you are asking them what they really mean.
dictionaryExamples: What do you think the poet is getting at in these lines?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The point I'm getting at is that you have to understand that young people look at sport[s] like school: it's something you do that makes you feel good afterward and computer games are something you do when you have some spare time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to leave or escape from a place or person, often when it is difficult to do this
dictionaryExamples: We walked to the next beach to get away from the crowds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] bicycle is a means of making new friends, and getting away from [your] daily routine. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to go somewhere for a short vacation, often  because you need to rest
dictionaryExamples: I just need to get away for a few days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've enjoyed the peace of getting away, you know I needed it. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to succeed in not being criticized or  punished for something
dictionaryExamples: If I thought I could get away with it, I wouldn't pay any tax at all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the police arrived, the criminals had already disappeared: they got away with this murder. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to return to a place after you have been somewhere else
dictionaryExamples: When we got back to the hotel, Ann had already left.
If you get back in time, you can come with us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Will call you when I get back. Preliminary English Test; B1; Gujarati

blocks.phrasalVerb: get back sth or get sth back

sense.def: to be given something again that you had before
dictionaryExamples: He went next door to get his ball back.
Don't lend him money, you'll never get it back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He hoped that he would get back his suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to talk or write to someone at a later time to give them some information they asked for or because you were not able to speak to them before
dictionaryExamples: I need to get back to Gary about his new computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am awfully sorry for having been slow in getting back to you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to make someone feel unhappy
dictionaryExamples: All this uncertainty is really getting me down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But when I had finally reached the bottom of the valley seeing the whole ski group staring at me, the embarras[s]ment got me down. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to start doing something seriously and with a lot of attention and effort
dictionaryExamples: Before we get down to business, I'd like to thank you all for coming today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's get down to business! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to succeed in entering a place, especially a building
dictionaryExamples: They must have gotten in through the bathroom window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [W]e had to hang out in front of the Museum for almost one hour. When we finally got in there, the tour was very short. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to arrive at a place at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: My flight gets in at 9:45 p.m.
When does Elaine get in?

sense.def: to succeed in being chosen or elected
dictionaryExamples: He wanted to go to Stanford, but he didn't get in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the first time I was trying to get in a University or a High College. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to succeed in being chosen or elected
dictionaryExamples: He got into Harvard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A month later on, I finally got into a High College of Education, but almost 400 km from home. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to become interested in an activity or subject, or start being involved in an activity
dictionaryExamples: How did you get into journalism?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking everything into account, I truly believe that "Ethnos" is the most suitable newspaper to be placed in the library [...] for every student who would like to learn Greek deeply and get into the Greek culture and civili[z]ation. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to leave a bus, train, aircraft or boat
dictionaryExamples: We should get off at the next stop.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then get off the bus in Obdland Village [and] walk up the road. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: to go onto a bus, train, aircraft or boat
dictionaryExamples: I think we got on the wrong bus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Saturday I was running to get on the bus, but my schoolbag was open and the diary fell [out]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to continue doing something, especially work
dictionaryExamples: We don’t have all day to finish this job, so can we just get on with it?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must go and get on with my homework. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to leave a closed vehicle, building, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I'll get out when you stop at the traffic light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly the lights went out and I was there, desper[ately] trying to find a way to get out of the house! First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to go out to different places and meet people in order to enjoy yourself
dictionaryExamples: She doesn't get out as much now that she had the baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since Internet, e-mails and mobile phones were invented, fewer people get out and meet friends. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to avoid doing something that you do not want to do, especially by giving an excuse
dictionaryExamples: If I can get out of going to the meeting tonight I will.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must go to Tokyo on business that Wednesday afternoon. This is a kind of step up for me and I can't get out of it. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to escape from or leave a place, or to help someone do this
dictionaryExamples: I left the door open and the cat got out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Don't panic, now, Lorraine", he answered me. "He may be a little .... um, eccentric, but I'm sure he'll get us out of here fine." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to get better after an illness, or feel better after something or someone has made you unhappy
dictionaryExamples: She's still getting over the flu.
It took her months to get over the shock of Richard leaving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, she had had to get over the deaths of three close relatives in the last three years. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be very shocked or surprised about something
dictionaryExamples: I can't get over how different you look with short hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can't get over how quickly you wrote to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to succeed in an examination or competition
dictionaryExamples: She got through her exams without too much trouble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you want to get through your exams. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to deal with a difficult or unpleasant experience, or to help someone do this
dictionaryExamples: My friendship with Carla got me through those tough months just after we moved.
We'll get you through this, Karen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You see, my friend, how li[f]e can be a bit difficult but people manage to get through it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to succeed in making someone understand or believe something
dictionaryExamples: I just don't seem to be able to get through to him these days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He should make the lesson interesting and should manage to get through to children. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to make someone feel upset or angry
dictionaryExamples: I know he's annoying but you shouldn't let him get to you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But they are overprotective and it gets to me very much. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to meet in order to do something or spend time together
dictionaryExamples: A few of us are getting together next week for a drink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During [a] Chinese wedding cer[e]mony, new couples wear traditional clothes and hold a party for friends and families getting together. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to stand up
dictionaryExamples: The whole audience got up and started clapping.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I got up on my feet again I reached out my arm to get a hold on something, but there w[as]n't anything to hold on to. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to wake up and get out of bed, or make someone do this
dictionaryExamples: I had to get up at five o'clock this morning.
Could you get the kids up?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend gets up early. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Panjabi

sense.def: the spirit of a dead person
dictionaryExamples: Do you believe in ghosts?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We saw a horror film. It was about ghosts and vampires! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: extremely large
dictionaryExamples: a giant spider
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Harry Potter fought with the giant snake and he won. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: an imaginary man who is much bigger and stronger than ordinary men
dictionaryExamples: The story is about a friendly giant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People have always seen him as a "big friendly giant", always ready to help those who are in need. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a very large and important company or organization
dictionaryExamples: a media/software giant
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In less than 15 years Bill Gates has built up his own company from scratch and turned it into a computer giant. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a present or something that is given
dictionaryExamples: a wedding gift
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The guitar was my father's gift. It is the best gift I've ever received. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a natural ability or skill
dictionaryExamples: She has a gift for design.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He understands the thought processes of children quite well, and has a gift for making difficult concepts understandable to youngsters, which obviously means he would be a very good supervisor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: A gifted person has a natural ability or is extremely intelligent.
dictionaryExamples: a gifted athlete
a school for gifted children
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Roger Federer is a young and extremely gifted tennis player. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Hungarian

sense.def: to laugh in a nervous or silly way
dictionaryExamples: She started giggling and couldn't stop.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Clara, a thin woman in her late fifties, giggled and her usually so flabby lips trembled as she did so. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: a large African animal with a very long neck and long legs
dictionaryExamples: Giraffes are the tallest land animals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Animals like elephants, giraffes and exotic birds must be free. How would you feel living inside a cage? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a female child or young woman
dictionaryExamples: Two girls showed us around the classrooms.
We have three children - a boy and two girls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has one girl. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Tigrinya

sense.def: a group of female friends
dictionaryExamples: I'm going out with the girls tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  We w[ere] dancing all night at the club [and] I really enjoyed my time with the girls. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: a woman or girl who someone is having a romantic relationship with
dictionaryExamples: I've never met his girlfriend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I danced with my mother and my girlfriend Maria. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a female friend of a girl or woman
dictionaryExamples: She's going out with her girlfriends tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I buy clothes once a month, and I usually go shopping with my mother or my girlfriends. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to provide someone with something
dictionaryExamples: Her parents gave her a car for her birthday.
Can you give me a date for another appointment?
Can you give this book to Andrea?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday was my birthday and my mother gave me a small dictionary. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to put something near someone or in their hand so that they can use it or look at it
dictionaryExamples: Can you give me that pen?
He poured a cup of coffee and gave it to Isabel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We gave the monkeys some bananas to eat and played with them. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: to telephone someone
dictionaryExamples: Why don't you just give him a call?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [If] you have other questions, you can give me a call. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: to tell someone something
dictionaryExamples: Can you give Jo a message?
The woman refused to give her name.
She gave me some really useful advice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I really hope you can give me some advice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to have a party
dictionaryExamples: They're always giving parties.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's a very nice guy, and I would like to give him a surprise party. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to allow someone to have a right or an opportunity
dictionaryExamples: We didn't really give him a chance to explain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll see you at seven o'clock to give you the chance to explain. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to produce or cause something
dictionaryExamples: What you said gives me an idea.
The sudden noise gave me quite a shock.
This announcement will give hope to millions of sufferers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope this [will] give you an idea of what I like. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to allow someone or something a particular amount of time
dictionaryExamples: I'm nearly ready - just give me a few minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you think you would be able to give me 2 hours more on Friday? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to pay someone a particular amount of money for something
dictionaryExamples: I gave him $40 for his old camera.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jeffry gave me a mechanical pen[ci]l while Jack and Eugene gave me twenty dollars. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: to perform an action
dictionaryExamples: She gave a cry.
He gave her a kiss on the cheek.
She gave me a big hug.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When he saw me, he gave me a big, warm hug and a sweet kiss. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to perform or speak in public
dictionaryExamples: Tony gave a great speech to open the conference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We would be very happy if you [could] come to our school and give a speech. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: When a woman or an animal gives birth, she produces a baby from her body.
dictionaryExamples: She gave birth to twins.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important person in my life is the person who gave birth to me, my mother. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when one thing or feeling changes to a different one
dictionaryExamples: My excitement gave way to fear when I drove a car for the first time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The feeling of anger they first had disappeared and gave way to a feeling of disappointment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to cause something
dictionaryExamples: The bacteria live in the human body but do not give rise to any symptoms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That visit gave rise to a fruitful discussion in which various opinions were voiced and here are some comments on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If something gives way, it falls because it is not strong enough to support the weight on top of it.
dictionaryExamples: The wooden seats gave way under the weight of the crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fred's voice trailed off as he felt his legs give way beneath him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: give sb the benefit of the doubt

sense.def: to choose to believe what someone tells you even though it may be wrong or a lie
dictionaryExamples: She says her train was late, so I suppose we'd better give her the benefit of the doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time our parents tell us ".. have you thought about it, are you sure you are not making a mistake?" we just answer "sure I have, no problem." Next time they do, let's give them the benefit of the doubt and let's think twice about the subject. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: give sb/have an edge on/over sb/sth

sense.def: to be slightly better than someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: Because of her experience she has an edge over the other applicants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Reading the latest information, attending conferences and s[y]mposiums and being well informed in general about your field, gives you an edge over your competitors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to criticize someone and make them feel guilty about something they have done
dictionaryExamples: Ever since I missed that catch, the other players have been giving me a hard time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not saying that I wasn't normal or anything, I just gave my family a hard time sometimes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrasalVerb: give away sth or give sth away

sense.def: to give something to someone without asking for payment
dictionaryExamples: The bakery is giving away a sample to every customer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She decided to give away everything she had and go to a place where nobody could find her. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to tell people something secret, often without intending to
dictionaryExamples: The party was supposed to be a surprise, but Sharon gave it away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave Matthew's secret away and this made his life come to an end. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

blocks.phrasalVerb: give back sth or give sth back

sense.def: to return something to the person who gave it to you
dictionaryExamples: Has she given you those books back yet?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please give it back to me tomorrow. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to finally agree to what someone wants, after refusing for a period of time
dictionaryExamples: He nagged me so much for a new bike that eventually I gave in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What you should do is talk to your parents and explain your problem to them. [Your] parents may give in! Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: to accept that you have been defeated and agree to stop competing or fighting
dictionaryExamples: You'll never guess the answer - do you give in?

blocks.phrasalVerb:
give out sth or
                give sth out

sense.def: to give something to a large number of people
dictionaryExamples: Please give these worksheets out, Maria.
I said I'd give out leaflets for them in town.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the concert, what I had to do was to give out refreshments to the audience. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

blocks.phrasalVerb: give up sth or give sth up

sense.def: to stop doing a regular activity or job
dictionaryExamples: We're going to give up our sports club membership after this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe that you should continue sports rather than music for as you mentioned in your letter you have always done sports and you can't give all that up for music classes. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: If you give up a habit, such as smoking, or something such as alcohol, you stop doing it or using it.
dictionaryExamples: I gave up smoking two years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason why he is not happy could be that he can't give up drinking so much and it gets him down. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to stop doing an activity or piece of work before you have completed it, usually because it is too difficult
dictionaryExamples: I had to give up halfway through the race.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important thing is that you should keep doing it. Don't give up!! First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: the willingness to accept some of another person's ideas and give up some of your own
dictionaryExamples: Any successful negotiation involves some give-and-take.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a give-and-take suggestion that in the sum up benefits the sector of population which is not under the coverage of state programs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: pleased and happy
dictionaryExamples: I'm glad (that) you came.
I'm so glad to see you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very glad to hear that. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: very willing to do something
dictionaryExamples: She's always glad to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know him personally and I'm sure he'll be very glad to help you. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to be grateful for something
dictionaryExamples: I'm glad of the opportunity to express my thanks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I lived in a very [nice] host family (I am very glad of it), but [it] was too big [a] distance from the school - about four miles. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the quality of being attractive, exciting and special
dictionaryExamples: Hollywood glamour
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The red carpet, the glamour, the glitter, the fame are things we all dream about at one point or another [in] our lives. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: strong, bright light that hurts your eyes
dictionaryExamples: I get a lot of glare from my computer screen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As often as not, pressing the switch gave no result or yielded the glare of a naked bulb. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a long, angry look
dictionaryExamples: She gave me an angry glare.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His glare [said] everything; she was the worst thing that had ever happened to the school. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to look at someone in an angry way
dictionaryExamples: She glared at him and stormed out of the room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You open the door and "Surprise!!": [it's] your mother and father, who ha[ve] just arrived from the country to spend the weekend with you. You glare at your mother, imagining that. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a hard transparent substance that objects such as windows and bottles are made of
dictionaryExamples: broken glass
a glass jar/vase
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The present I love[d] the most was a cute little cat made from glass. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a container made of glass that is used for drinking
dictionaryExamples: Would you like a glass of water?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Usually for breakfast we have some sandwiches with cheese and ham and [a] glass of milk. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a piece of equipment with two transparent parts that you wear in front of your eyes to help you see better
dictionaryExamples: a pair of glasses
She was wearing glasses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Roger, I think I have left my glasses in the kitchen. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you see something or someone for a very short time
dictionaryExamples: He caught/got a glimpse of her as she got into the car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you go to Canada, like I did, you will enjoy great camping in the Rockies and might even catch a glimpse of the famous bears. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: relating to the whole world
dictionaryExamples: a global disaster
the global problem of nuclear waste
the global economy
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The improvement of electronics and global communications has made it possible to keep [in] close contact with friends all over the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the process by which businesses operate in many different countries and the culture of different countries becomes more similar
dictionaryExamples: the globalization of fashion
Optimists say globalization means more choices for everyone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These dishes have been eaten for generations.  However, globalization and changing work patterns have changed traditions in big cities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: in a way that relates to the whole world
dictionaryExamples:
The company has to be able to compete
                         globally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since I went to Canada, I realized we should think about environmental pollution globally. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: a gradual increase in world temperatures caused by polluting gases
dictionaryExamples: Very few people now deny that global warming is caused by humankind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, due to global warming, sea levels might rise and [the] risk of flooding will also rise. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when people praise and respect you for achieving something important
dictionaryExamples: It was my idea, but she got all the glory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This point of view states that it is more fulfilling for a single person to achieve a goal on [their] own, without having to share the glory with other people and that by doing it alone, one really feels that [one] has achieved something. International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: the quality of being very impressive or beautiful
dictionaryExamples: The castle has been restored to its former glory.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Two years ago, the state, helped by the community of the island, gave birth to an ambitious plan to restore this beach to its former glory. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a piece of clothing which covers your fingers and hand
dictionaryExamples: a pair of gloves
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Remember to bring gloves as well. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a soft, warm light
dictionaryExamples: the warm glow of the moon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sun was setting, leaving a pink glow on everything it touched and the air smelled like fresh-cut grass. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: when your face feels or appears warm and healthy
dictionaryExamples: Sam's face had lost its rosy glow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After about three weeks of using this product by Morway Company, you will notice that your face looks softer and has a natural healthy glow. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to produce a soft, warm light
dictionaryExamples: toys that glow in the dark
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can safely invest [i]n juggling equipment that glows in the dark, has flashing lights - or even that is set afire before starting to juggle [with] it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to have a warm and healthy appearance
dictionaryExamples: Her eyes were bright and her cheeks were glowing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While the tourists were getting dressed, Ingrid, a tall middle-aged woman, checked the humidity of her armpits and that reminded her of the sentence: "Horses sweat, men perspire, women glow." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to feel very happy, proud, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Glowing with pride, she showed me her painting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I never use it, of course, but just knowing I possess it makes me glow with happiness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a substance used to stick things together
dictionaryExamples: Put a little glue on both edges and hold them together.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the contrary, sometimes, with the help of our teachers, we had to fix them using "emergency" solutions and materials, such as tape and glue. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to stick something to something else with glue
dictionaryExamples: Do you think you can glue this vase back together?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That is why my father glued and nailed the back of it so nobody could ever open the frame. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to be watching something, especially television
dictionaryExamples: The kids were glued to the TV all morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general, it can be said that the modern mass obsession with television has led to the fact that more people now[a]days lead a sedentary way of life, not to mention [their being] couch potatoes, glued to the screen [for] most of their leisure time. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to move or travel somewhere
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to go to Japan.
He went into the house.
Are you going by train?
Does this train go to Newcastle?
Where did Helena go?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to go to Hawaii. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hindi

sense.def: to move or travel somewhere in order to do something
dictionaryExamples: Let's go for a walk.
We're going camping on Friday.
I have to go and pick the kids up now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also have a dog and I like to go for a walk with [him]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to visit stores in order to buy things
dictionaryExamples: We went shopping last Saturday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We often go shopping. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to go somewhere to do a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: We went skating yesterday.
We're going camping on Friday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to go swimming. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to intend to do or be something
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to call her tonight.
I'm going to be a dancer when I grow up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to paint my bedroom yellow. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to say that something is expected to happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: It's going to snow tonight.
They're going to have their first baby in June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's going to rain [tomorrow]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to empty the body of urine or solid waste, usually using a toilet in a bathroom
dictionaryExamples: It's going to be a long ride, kids, so if you need to go to the bathroom do it now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Where did he leave [his suitcase]? He was going to miss his flight.  He remembered he had gone to the bathroom! He hurried and found his suitcase! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to develop in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: My exams went really well.
"How did your interview go?" "Pretty badly."
Something's gone wrong with my computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope everything is going well. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to develop problems
dictionaryExamples: Something's gone wrong with my computer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Despite all that went wrong, there was something I really enjoyed. It was visiting the Diamond Cave. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to disappear or no longer exist
dictionaryExamples: The food was all gone by the time we got to the party.
When I turned around, the man had gone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I came to take my suitcase, it had gone! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If two things go, they match each other.
dictionaryExamples: That top doesn't go with these pants.
This jacket and skirt don't go together do they?

sense.def: to become bald/blind/gray, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He went bald in his twenties.

sense.def: If a road, path, etc. goes in a particular direction, it leads there.
dictionaryExamples: This road goes north to Vermont.

sense.def: If you ask for some food to go at a restaurant, you are asking for food that you can take away with you instead of eating it in the restaurant.
dictionaryExamples: I'd like a cheeseburger and strawberry milk shake to go, please.

sense.def: to have a particular tune or words
dictionaryExamples: I can't remember how his latest song goes.

sense.def: If time goes, it passes.
dictionaryExamples: The day went very quickly.
There are only two  weeks of school to go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But the time went so quickly and now I am in my early sixties [with] a lot of spare time. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to make a particular sound or movement
dictionaryExamples: A cat goes "Miaow."
"Your dog's acting strange!" - "He  goes like that when he wants some food."

sense.def: to work in the right way
dictionaryExamples: Did you get the car going?

sense.def: to stop working correctly
dictionaryExamples: She's very old and her hearing is going.

sense.def: to tell or include all the facts about something
dictionaryExamples: I won't go into detail over the phone, but I've been having a few health problems recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In one of his books he really goes into detail [about] how children treat other children [who] have difficulties with their "new" [language]. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone goes red, their face becomes red because they are embarrassed or angry.
dictionaryExamples: He kissed her on the cheek and she went bright red.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Paul saw the girl who had got blond hair and bluish eyes, his face suddenly went red. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If something goes without saying, it is obvious or generally accepted.
dictionaryExamples: It goes without saying that smoking is harmful to your health.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It goes without saying that I will participate! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If two things go hand in hand, they exist together and are connected with each other.
dictionaryExamples: Prosperity goes hand in hand with investment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Traffic and pollution go hand in hand. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: to provide what someone needs for a short period of time
dictionaryExamples: Dinner is at eight, but I had an apple to keep me going.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because of health concerns, advertisements lately show the people in Holland how important it is to have a good breakfast and that it will keep you going the whole day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to gradually become worse
dictionaryExamples: After his wife died, his health started to go downhill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had been going downhill in the last few days and so his death came as no surprise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrase: go so far as to do sth

sense.def: to take the extreme action of doing something
dictionaryExamples: He even went so far as to stop her using the telephone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our present course of action may go so far as to cause irrevers[i]ble damage not only to our planet but also to the people living upon [it]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to behave in a way that upsets or annoys other people
dictionaryExamples: He's said some stupid things in the past, but this time he's gone too far.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lucia let her speak and calmly said: "You really have gone too far this time." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to do or accept what other people are doing because it is the easiest thing to do
dictionaryExamples: Just relax and go with the flow!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At this stage of her progress towards knowing herself better she has accepted that life is a mu[dd]le and that to a certain extent one has to go with the flow. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something goes against the grain, it is something you would not normally do.
dictionaryExamples: It goes against the grain to throw all this food away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She tries to dodge George because she is afraid of admitting the fact that she loves him. It simply goes against the grain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to do something because you are expected to do it and not because you want to
dictionaryExamples: Lately he seems to just go through the motions and doesn't enjoy the job at all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She went through the motions of every-day-life without enthusiasm. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to do something too much, or to be too excited about something
dictionaryExamples: I think I went overboard cooking this dinner – there is enough to feed a dozen people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While no one should restrict their eating habits to the point eating is no longer a pleasure, but rather a chore, it is important not to go overboard, completely disregarding the advice of nutrition experts. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: go out of your way to do sth

sense.def: to try very hard to do something pleasant for someone
dictionaryExamples: He went out of his way to make us feel welcome.

sense.def: continuing to be successful or healthy after a long time
dictionaryExamples: The club was set up in 1987, and it's still going strong.
He's 93 and still going strong!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am proud of him and happy that he is still going strong. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Finnish

sense.def: to start to do something
dictionaryExamples: We now have permission to go ahead with the project.
The vote will go ahead today as planned.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I felt depressed under my parents' pressure, but I had something stronger deep inside of me saying that I should go ahead with my [plan]. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: something that you say to someone to allow them to do something
dictionaryExamples: "Can I borrow your book?" - "Yes, go ahead."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everyone needs something sweet from time to time. Go ahead but don't eat it too often, eat more fruit and veg[e]tables! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to leave a place
dictionaryExamples: Just go away and leave me alone, will you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] big dog appeared. We were very scared. However, the dog went away and we [were able to] spend a beautiful day, walking, and breathing clean air. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to leave your home in order to spend time in a different place
dictionaryExamples: We're going away for a few weeks in the summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandparents had gone away for a week. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to return to a place where you were or where you have been before
dictionaryExamples: When are you going back to Paris?
It had started to rain so I went back for my keys.
Is she well enough to go back to work?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I went back to the classroom, picked up my bag and went home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: If time goes by, it passes.
dictionaryExamples: The days went by really slowly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The night went by slowly and my family and I had a great time and a lot of fun. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to become lower in level
dictionaryExamples: House prices have gone down recently.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Here in my city the temperature is going down, in the newspaper I read that this winter may be the coldest in many years so I'[d] like to buy a coat soon. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: When the sun goes down, it moves down in the sky until it cannot be seen any more.
dictionaryExamples: I sat with Ken and Olga and watched the sun go down.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Late in the [evening] we can go to the beach and see the sun go down. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: to choose something
dictionaryExamples: I don't know whether to go for the fish or the steak.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, in your next letter, let me know what kind of shopping you go for. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to try to get or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: He'll be going for his fifth Olympic gold medal.
"I'm going to apply for that job." "Yeah, go for it!"

sense.def: to enter a place
dictionaryExamples: I looked through the window but I didn't go in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Surprisingly there w[as] no one in the house so I used the key to open the door [and] then I went in.  First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to leave a place and go somewhere else
dictionaryExamples: They've gone off to the diner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Luckily someone came along soon afterwards and they went off to phone for an ambulance which brought us here. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If a light or machine goes off, it stops working.
dictionaryExamples: The heating goes off at 10 o'clock.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Suddenly the computer shut down and the light went off. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: If something that makes a noise goes off, it suddenly starts making a noise.
dictionaryExamples: His car alarm goes off every time it rains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately one of those buttons was the alarm which should be pressed in case of fire and it went off and all the staff from the restaurant came downstairs quickly. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: If a bomb or a gun goes off, it explodes or fires.
dictionaryExamples: A bomb went off in the parking lot, killing three people.

sense.def: to continue to happen or exist
dictionaryExamples: The meeting went on until six o'clock.
The path seemed to go on forever.
I know she's upset about losing her job, but life goes on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jonathan, this can't go on any more, this week you spent with me I could see you have been working too hard. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to happen
dictionaryExamples: Why aren't they here yet? What's going on?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "What is going on?", I asked. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to continue doing something
dictionaryExamples: We can't go on living like this.
She went on talking as though nothing had happened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are many people who think that even if technology improves, our lifestyles will not change much. They think we will go on dealing with problems at home as we [have always done]. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to leave a place in order to go somewhere else
dictionaryExamples: Are you going out tonight?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to go out with my friends. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Pashto

sense.def: If two people go out together, they have a romantic relationship with each other.
dictionaryExamples: I've been going out with Peter for a year.
Dan and I have been going out for over two years now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her name is Francesca and I met her at university. She is very nice, so we decided to go out together. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: If a light or something that is burning goes out, it stops producing light or heat.
dictionaryExamples: Should I put some more wood on the fire or let it go out?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have never beli[e]ved in ghost[s], but why did the lights go out? First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to examine something, such as a piece of writing or some numbers, in order to make sure that it is correct
dictionaryExamples: I'm just going over these figures one more time.

sense.def: to experience a difficult or unpleasant situation or event
dictionaryExamples: She's going through a difficult time at her job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We went through a dreadful experience you can be sure. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to become higher in level
dictionaryExamples: Food prices keep going up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You should have a lot of money because the cost of li[ving] is going up. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a point scored in sports such as soccer, when a player sends a ball or other object into a particular area, such as between two posts
dictionaryExamples: He scored two goals in the second half.
We won by three goals to one.
Brinkworth scored the winning goal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I scored ten goals. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: in some sports, the area between two posts, where players try to send the ball or other object
dictionaryExamples: Terry headed the ball towards the goal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I usually play in goal, but sometimes I play in attack too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: an aim or purpose
dictionaryExamples: Do you think I'll be able to achieve my goal of losing 10 pounds?
Andy's goal is to run in the New York Marathon.
Always set realistic goals for yourself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My goal for the future is to be a sail boat captain and this trip would be a good opportunity to practise my skills. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the player who stands in the team's goal to try to stop the other team from scoring
dictionaryExamples: He was his college soccer team's goalkeeper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a very good goalkeeper. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an animal with horns which is kept to provide milk, meat, etc.
dictionaryExamples: goat cheese
goat's milk
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can enjoy watching camels and goats passing once in the morning and [again] in the evening. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: a valuable, shiny, yellow metal used to make coins, jewelry, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The bracelet was made of solid gold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's ma[d]e of gold and very expensive. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: made of gold
dictionaryExamples: gold jewelry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sammy gave me a gold ring. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: being the bright yellow color of gold
dictionaryExamples: gold paint
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided paint my bedroom red and gold! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: made of gold
dictionaryExamples: a golden ring
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Marinella, I have left my golden ring at your house. Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: being the bright yellow color of gold
dictionaryExamples: her golden hair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a mermaid Barbie with long golden hair. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: special, successful, or giving someone an advantage
dictionaryExamples: He has a golden opportunity to do research.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, my uncle has some friends in the music world and it was a golden opportunity when he asked me to [help] at the Tina Turner concert! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a game on grass where players try to hit a small ball into a series of holes, using a long, thin stick
dictionaryExamples: Do you play golf?
We often play a round of golf on Saturdays.
a golf course
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We could go to a golf course and play golf. Key English Test; A2; Swedish

sense.def: enjoyable, pleasant or interesting
dictionaryExamples: a good book/film
Did you have a good time at the party?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think we [will] have [a] good time. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: of a high quality or level
dictionaryExamples: She speaks good French.
The food at this restaurant is very good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes eat[ing] good food from Argentina, for example barbecue[d meat] and salad. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Spanish

sense.def: something you say when you are pleased about what someone has said
dictionaryExamples: "I'm coming on Saturday." "Oh, good!"
"She's really making progress." "Good!"

sense.def: something that you say when a person asks how you are  or how someone you know is
dictionaryExamples: "How are you, Amelia?" "I'm good, thanks!"
"How's Joshua doing?" "He's good, thank you."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi, Jo Is your family good? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: successful, or able to do something well
dictionaryExamples: Kate's a good cook.
She's very good at geography.
He's very good with children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He's [a] good football player. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: kind or helpful
dictionaryExamples: a good friend
He's very good to his mother.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a good friend. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lingala

sense.def: making you healthy or happy
dictionaryExamples: Swimming is really good for you.
Eating plenty of fresh vegetables is good for you
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think playing basketball is good for you. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: suitable or satisfactory
dictionaryExamples: Is this a good time to talk?
When would it be a good time to phone?
How about Friday - is that good for you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Saturday is good for me, I hope that [it] is good for you. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: A good child or animal behaves well.
dictionaryExamples: If you're a good boy at the doctor's I'll take you swimming afterward.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I made a promis[e], I['ll be] the good child for two months, later I['ll] return [to being] the devil child you know! Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: morally right
dictionaryExamples: He's a very good person.
Try to set a good example for the children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only in this way can [we] give a good example to the new generation. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: If it's a good thing that something happened, it is lucky or fortunate that it happened.
dictionaryExamples: It's a good thing (that) we bought our tickets early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's a good thing that your parents [are going to] come, because [...] maybe it would make it easier for you to convince them to let you spend a week here during Xmas. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show approval for someone's success or good luck
dictionaryExamples: You passed your exam?  Good for you!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's great news! Good for you! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: used to emphasize the number, amount, quality, etc., of something
dictionaryExamples: There was a good deal of discussion about how much the car was worth.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Your children have a good chance of getting a better education. International English Language Testing System; C1; Farsi

sense.def: an agreement, arrangement, or situation that benefits you
dictionaryExamples: I think we got a really good deal on our new car.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The possibility [of] get[ting] the needed staff from our own departments is absolutely a good deal for the company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to be a pleasant or interesting person to spend time with
dictionaryExamples: Ann and Charles are always good company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is a bit narrow-minded and at first he'll drive you crazy, but once you get to know him he'll be good company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not less than 20 minutes/30 miles, etc. and probably a little more
dictionaryExamples: It takes a good half hour to get downtown to the office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Arts and Social science field also has a good 21% of graduates in further study. International English Language Testing System; C2; French

sense.def: used to say that something has gone well until now
dictionaryExamples: It's the first time I've done any decorating, but so far, so good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So far, so good, only no one told us they held this point of view before the actual christening took place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be acceptable in a way that will not upset or anger people
dictionaryExamples: His speech was in good taste.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I therefore t[h]ought that it would be in good taste to write about two of them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: something that is an advantage or help to a person or situation
dictionaryExamples: Even a small donation can do a lot of good.
It's hard work, but it's for your own good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please think about this, [it] is for your own good. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: be no good or be not any/much good

sense.def: to not be useful, helpful or valuable
dictionaryExamples: Boots are no good if they aren't waterproof.
Food aid isn't much good until the fighting stops.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When [it] is raining, you get wet and that's no good to anyone. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to have a good effect on someone
dictionaryExamples: A vacation in the sun will do you  good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that living and studying in another country will do you good. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: forever
dictionaryExamples: When he was 20, he left home for good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was renting this property previously, but he went back to Sri Lanka for good. International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese

sense.def: something that people think is morally right or will help  others
dictionaryExamples: Even a small donation can do a lot of good.
Children don't always understand the difference between good and bad.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From a symbolic point of view, the whole book features the conflict between good and evil, between reason and primary brutal p[as]sions such as savageness and lust for blood. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: something you say to someone when you meet them in the afternoon
dictionaryExamples: Good afternoon, Cara.

sense.def: something you say when you leave someone or when they leave you
dictionaryExamples: Goodbye Marcos! See you next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Goodbye for now. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: something you say to greet someone in the evening
dictionaryExamples: Good evening, everyone.

sense.def: If someone is good-looking, they have an attractive face.
dictionaryExamples: He's very good-looking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The teacher is a very young and good-looking woman. Preliminary English Test; B1; [no L1 data]

sense.def: something you say to greet someone when you meet them in the morning
dictionaryExamples: Good morning, Joe - how are you today?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you come in clas[s] he say[s] hi good morning every body. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Arabic

sense.def: the quality of being good
dictionaryExamples: She believes in the goodness of human nature.
