sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like reggae and ska music music, especially NSK, a very good ska group. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to form a group or put people or things into a group or groups
dictionaryExamples: The children are grouped according to their ability.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to suggest that we should be grouped according to the level of our English proficienc[y] on the first day of the semester. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to develop and become bigger or taller as time passes
dictionaryExamples: Children grow so quickly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I['ve] grown and the dress is too t[ight] for me. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: If a plant grows, or you grow it, it develops from a seed to a full plant.
dictionaryExamples: Tomatoes grow well in full sun.
The villagers grow coffee and maize to sell in the market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will grow many new trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to increase
dictionaryExamples: The number of people living alone grows each year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In Rio, violence is growing very fast, so if we're planning to spend the holiday [i]n the city we'll have to take care. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If your hair or nails grow, or if you grow them, they get longer.
dictionaryExamples: Are you growing a beard?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've lost some weight and I've grown a beard. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to gradually become tired/old/calm, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Our bodies change as we grow older.
The music was growing louder and louder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They went to the field and, relaxing on [the] grass, spoke about their life without each other. Soft blue evening came and it was growing dark. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to gradually become an adult
dictionaryExamples: I grew up in Scotland.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have grown up eating this kind of food. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: increasing in size or quantity
dictionaryExamples: There is a growing awareness of the seriousness of this disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One big change [in] the last ten years is definitely the growing interest in more natural and healthy food. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: an adult, used especially when talking to children
dictionaryExamples: Ask a grown-up to cut the shape out for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I were a grown-up I would like to have a big dog. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: If you say that someone is grown-up, you mean that they are an adult or that they behave in a responsible way.
dictionaryExamples: She has two grown-up children who work in the family business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now, as a grown-up person, I am trying to evaluate such [an] upbringing objectively. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: when something grows, increases or develops
dictionaryExamples: A balanced diet is essential for healthy growth.
population growth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The huge growth of technology has brought lots of good aspects to my life, like the facility to be informed about everything that is happening around the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: easily annoyed and often complaining
dictionaryExamples: a grumpy old man
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, our coach driver was a grumpy, unpleasant man who was not even polite enough to answer our questions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to promise or make sure that something is true or will happen
dictionaryExamples: Every child is guaranteed a place at a public school.
They guarantee that it will arrive on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can guarantee you won't be disappointed if you let me do the job. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a written promise made by a company to repair one of its products or give you a new one if it has a fault
dictionaryExamples: a money-back guarantee
I'm afraid this camera is no longer under guarantee.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And you couldn't [take] it back because  it is not under guarantee. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a promise that something will be done or will happen
dictionaryExamples: There's no guarantee that it actually works.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are the ones who are hit most by any economic deterioration or crisis, and there is no guarantee that they will not end up living in the streets. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: someone whose job is to protect a person, place or thing from danger or attack, or to prevent a person such as a criminal from escaping
dictionaryExamples: a security guard
prison guards
The frontier is patrolled by border guards.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw two security guards, who opened the door for me and welcomed me inside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Albanian

sense.def: to surprise someone by doing something when they are not ready to deal with it
dictionaryExamples: The journalist caught him off guard and he admitted to lying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It caught me off guard. This grotesque image shattered the comfort of a languid Sunday afternoon and for a few seconds hurled me into a world of pain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be ready to deal with something difficult that might happen
dictionaryExamples: Companies were warned to be on their guard for suspicious packages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, we should be on guard, so as not to let the things escape our control. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to relax when you should be careful or ready to deal with something
dictionaryExamples: He's worried that if he lets his guard down someone may take advantage of him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That of course will go against anything Stevens has ever done and he never lets his guard down. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to protect someone or something from being attacked or stolen
dictionaryExamples: Soldiers guard the main doors of the embassy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess it was that thrill that actually made me anxious to know what really was going on inside the dodgy-looking old house guarded by a man with an unfriendly hound. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to watch someone and make certain they do not escape from a place
dictionaryExamples: Five prison officers guarded the prisoners.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No one was g[u]arding him. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who comes to visit you in your home, at a party, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We've got some guests coming this weekend.
There were 90 guests at their wedding.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were fifty guests at my party. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a person who is staying in a hotel
dictionaryExamples: We would like to remind all our guests to leave their keys at reception before they depart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And if you are a guest of the hotel, they'll give you a beautiful flower. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: a person, such as an entertainer, who has been invited to appear on a television or radio program or in a performance
dictionaryExamples: Our guest tonight is Robert de Niro.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course a bear shouldn't be a guest [o]n a TV show, it's not in his nature. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: help or  advice
dictionaryExamples: spiritual/expert guidance
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I dream of being Lord Krishna's devotee but I need professional guidance. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: someone whose job is to show interesting places to visitors, or to help people get somewhere
dictionaryExamples: a tour guide
The guide at the museum gave us a very interesting talk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I visited the "White House" and the guide was very friendly. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a book that gives information about something or tells you how to do something
dictionaryExamples: a hotel/restaurant guide
a user's guide
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I found that some of the current information in the guide [is] a little bit old. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to help someone visit a place or go somewhere
dictionaryExamples: Someone offered to guide us through the jungle.
He gently guided her back to her seat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to look after the members of the public and [I] guided them to their s[ea]ts. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a book that gives visitors information about a particular place
dictionaryExamples: a guidebook to/about Venice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The rest of the holiday I'll dedicate to tourism with my guidebook, [getting to] know the best places o[n] the island. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: advice about how to do something
dictionaryExamples: government guidelines
The EU has issued guidelines on appropriate levels of pay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To avoid being injured, you must follow all the guidelines provided by your employer. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: a feeling of shame or unhappiness when you have done something wrong
dictionaryExamples: He suffered such feelings of guilt over leaving his children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her brother had hesitated before telling her the truth, but he proved that he really trusted his sister by confessing his guilt to her. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: the fact of having committed a crime
dictionaryExamples: Both suspects admitted their guilt to the police.

sense.def: feeling guilt
dictionaryExamples: She was so upset about what I'd said and I felt so guilty.
I felt guilty about leaving her there on her own.
I've got a guilty conscience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've got a guilty conscience because I forg[o]t to say goodbye. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: responsible for breaking a law
dictionaryExamples: The jury found her guilty.
The jury has to decide whether a person is guilty or innocent of a crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the trial, where the jury found him guilty, he was sent to prison for a long time. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a musical instrument with six strings and a long neck which is usually made of wood, and which is played by pulling or hitting the strings with the fingers
dictionaryExamples: an acoustic/electric guitar
Do you play the guitar?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can play the guitar quite well. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who plays the guitar, especially as their job
dictionaryExamples: The lead guitarist in the band was excellent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not only did he want to be a doctor, but he was also a great guitarist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: an area of sea surrounded on three sides by land
dictionaryExamples: the Gulf of Mexico/the Gulf Coast
We traveled west along the gulf.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart the view of the gulf, Vesuvio, etc., the best thing of Napoli is the nightlife. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: an important difference between the opinions or situations of two groups of people
dictionaryExamples: There is a growing gulf between the rich and the poor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While Mrs. Kingshaw simplifies and triviali[z]es her son's fears, she increases the gulf between them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the hard, pink part inside your mouth that your teeth grow out of
dictionaryExamples: Protect your teeth and gums by visiting your dentist regularly.

sense.def: a sweet substance that you chew but do not swallow
dictionaryExamples: a stick of gum

sense.def: a weapon that you fire bullets out of
dictionaryExamples: You could hear the noise of guns firing in the distance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He went downstairs and picked up his father's gun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: the bravery and determination that is needed to do something difficult or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: It took guts to stand up and tell the boss how she felt.
I didn't think he would have the guts to quite that awful job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They did not expect that the people [in] this vicinity would actually have the guts to retaliate! First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: the organs inside a person's or animal's body
dictionaryExamples: Its guts were spilled all over the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The walls were covered in blood and their guts were spilled all over the place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a man
dictionaryExamples: Do you mean the guy with the blond hair and glasses?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last night, I met a wonderful guy! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you are talking to or about two or more people
dictionaryExamples: Come on, you guys, let's go home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hey guys! I'm just writing to thank you [for] the great times we had last weekend and to say you're aw[e]some. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a building or room with equipment for doing exercise
dictionaryExamples: Nick goes to the gym three times a week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We went to a gym near my house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a school class in which children learn to exercise and play sports
dictionaryExamples: We have gym on Friday afternoons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can do gym, aqua, dance, boxing, squash, [and] tennis. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: involving gymnastics
dictionaryExamples: a gymnastic display
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My friend like[s] to go swimming every morning. I prefer to [do] gymnastic exercises in a separate room every day. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a sport in which you do physical exercises on the floor and on different pieces of equipment, often in competitions
dictionaryExamples: Let's watch the gymnastics on TV.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every Tuesday and Thursday you can [do] sports like basketball, football or also gymnastics. Preliminary English Test; B1; German
